reviewText:
That was awesome!

Would love to have seen more interaction and the ability to 'walk' around on the moon with the Vive, but aside from the desire for more simulation... Apollo 11 VR was a wonderful, emotional experience and totally worth the price of admission.

As a developer also working in VR, I've tried dozens of VR experiences, and this is one of my favorites. Highly recommend.

reviewText: Anyone with a Rift or Vive should buy this. Although it's pretty short (played through in just under 1 1/2 hours with interaction mode enabled) the production values and attention to detail are nothing short of amazing and it really shows what the future of learning will be like in the coming years :) Would recommend this to anyone.
voteText: 43 of 51 people (84%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I don't write many reviews.  This might only be my second. However I felt compelled to write about this experience.

It is....breathtaking. I never dreamt that I would one day know what it felt like to sit in the capsule. Listening to the countdown and commentry. Heart rate increasing. Tension building. Sat with a Rift on in a living room in England and yet transported to Cape Canaveral on that bright July morning.

When you hear those main engines start, I swear you can feel them. That immense power, held in place by the clamps. Then zero is reached and the clamps release. Through the window, a cloud slowly moves past, followed by another one, only faster. White wisps flash by the window now and suddenly, you can see the Earth, slowly falling away.

You realise you haven't breathed for 20 seconds and when you exhale, a big fat tear runs down your cheek. Man, this is emotional. -and then you stage. The main engines cut off, leaving you in a breathless silence. You are in Earth orbit. A quick glance around the cabin leaves you in no doubt. It was then that the full emotional impact of what I'd just experienced hit me like the business end of a Saturn V. I literally cried like a baby. I had experienced spaceflight.

The rest of the experince takes you to further stages of the flight. Leaving Earth orbit, docking with the LEM, moon orbit, insertion and finally landing. Oh boy. Looking out of the window of the Eagle and seeing the Moon's surface getting closer, having a slight panic at the 1202 alarm and finally, touching down in the Sea of Tranquility. All priceless moments.

History will remember Neil's first steps as the defining moment of the Apollo mission, but for this VR experience, the flights were the best parts. Your mileage may vary.

TLDR: Buy it. Support it. It's the best educational use of VR so far and if it doesn't move you to tears, then maybe  you don't cry at stuff. :)

10/10 Would be an astronaut again.

Froobyone

reviewText: This has some great moments but it could have been better. For single purpose, limited scope experiences like this, I expect higher quality assets. Textures are lacking, especially orbital and ascent views of the Earth and Moon. The feeling of presence inside the spacecraft is excellent, but just when you want to reach out and flip a switch you realize you can't. The lunar surface is lacking in detail - this is only marginally better than any random spot on the Mun in Kerbal. Don't get me wrong, this has great moments. The Saturn V assembled for launch is great just for the scale of the thing. But as a paid VR experience, focusing on less than an hour's worth of content, I think the bar should be higher. The lunar surface needs footprints and regolith that gives way. There needs to something to do for ascent and docking with the command module for return.
voteText: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
It is not a game, it is a once in a lifetime experience, and one we get to be part of for the first time - remember only 12 people have ever actually made this trip!

Having backed and followed this project since it first appeared on Kickstarter, I have enjoyed watching the project mature over the past 12 months or so and experiencing the various sequences that were provided to backers, I am pleased to say that the final product is everything I hoped for; accurate, poingant, exciting, uplifting, mesmerising, and so much, much more. If you have any interest in space flight, or the Apollo program, and/or you have the system and VR capabilities, then this is an absolute must.

Several intersting parts of the first lunar landing flight are represented in short sequences, from launchpad to splashdown, they are all enjoyable, but all are over far sooner than you would like (no fault of the software, just greed on my part). You will find your favourite sequences too, and have the ability to go back and watch them again at your leisure.

The liftoff sequence alone is worth every penny in my opinion, and may never get boring to be part of; this is proper hair on the back of your neck standing up" material. All of the sequences are."

If you don't like the price, I highly recommend picking this up on a sale!

reviewText: A powerful experience. I was misty-eyed by the end of it. The coolest virtual field trip I've ever taken.\n\nLanding on the moon took a lot of tries, but I eventually made it down. A few things to note: you're initially off-center to the left, so you need to immediately start thrusting to the right to get lined up, or you'll fail because you flew too far away". Your lander is automatically thrusting upwards at a steady amount; your job is to control the angle to adjust your forward speed and descent. The thrust (up on the analog stick) is to help slow your descent
date: but thrusting kills your vertical velocity fairly quickly
recommended: so don't use it too much initially or you won't descend quickly enough - however
hoursPlayed: it also increases the power of your pitch and translate.\n\nDon't use the "angle" markers on the window as absolutes - they're probably going to be innaccurate if you're trying to figure out if you're level or not
voteText: because they depend on your head position. Instead
helpfulPercent: use the attitude gauge in the cockpit just to the right of the angle markers on the window: each grid on it is about 10 degrees. Finally
votesHelpful: pitching forward will increase your ground speed and your rate of descent. Pitching backwards will decrease your ground speed and increase your rate of descent. Pitching so you're straight up and down will keep your forward speed steady and will give you the slowest descent. There's no vertical speed indicator to match the ground speed indicator
votesTotal: but the altitude indicator changes every second
votesFunny: so you can get a pretty good idea of how quickly you're descending. You can also look up videos of the Apollo descents on youtube to get a feel for their trajectory: how fast they were descending

reviewText:
I expected to witness a whole journey to the moon, but it ends up like this:
You stand in home cinema and see old videos.
.....LOADING SCREEN.....
You get motion sick as soon as you see the rocket from outside while you getting dragged around it.
.....LOADING SCREEN.....
You are suddenly in an elevator.
.....LOADING SCREEN.....
You are in a Rocket but you can wark outside of your body (Game dosen't adapt to your position in the room).
.....LOADING SCREEN.....
You now see the earth and the spaceship from outside while floating in space **more motion sickness**
.....LOADING SCREEN.....
You are now 15 min into the game and get asked again if you want to take over controll, to start docking. F**K YES!
But you get now explanation how :( After 4 puzzling tryes I was so frustrated that I closed the game and refunded it.

Just boring and half-baked!

reviewText:
A truly breathtaking experience!

You can see the love that went into this, just by looking at the details. Things like stars that fade when you're looking at the moon surface and reappear when you look up, indicate that this is a really well thought out experience.

Don't expect a spectacular Hollywood sci-fi production, but instead an historically accurate, but also visually stunning account of the journey that really makes you appreciate the huge achievement of the Apollo program.

The storytelling and the music complement the visuals, making this a must see experience.

reviewText:
Wow,

The screenshots and videos don't do it justice. I've been using VR for a while now so thought I was over that laugh-out-loud feeling you get when you first put on a headset. This put me right back there in that happy place.

An excellent experience. Very much worth it.
WOW. Very cool VR documentary. There are some really magic transitions and little interactive moments between you and the crew.
A beautiful, moving simulation. A few disturbing camera shifts but overall a wonderful experience. Thanks to Immersive VR Education for making this.

I had tried the demos throughout the development of this experience, but the final product is so much more fleshed out. I'd love to list everything I absolutely loved, but I'd be listing every single moment.

I played it with a DK2, and everything worked perfectly.

Well done!
This is one of the most amazing things I've experienced.

Nicely done.  A very comfortable experience, and the interactive parts are fun, though certainly not especially challenging (but I'm biased that way, most people won't have a flight background... so it's probably a good fit/challenge for the average viewer).

The models are decent... and the rendering smooth and effective.  It's a great way for people that weren't around during that heady time to have a taste of what the world experienced watching this unfold.

Another great way to introduce people to VR.

This was literally awesome.
If you have even the slightest interest in spaceflight (and own a Rift/Vive) you NEED to get this.
For your first playthrough it might be a good idea to use the cinematic mode for the moon landing part, it took me more than ten tries to do it.
Only complaint I have is that it got a bit hard to see things at the end from all the tears :D

Apollo 11 VR is a brilliant program especially now you have updated it for keyboard control very realistic i have waited along time for a good apollo simulator ,maybe it would be good to have a bit more interaction added to the sim ie the stages on takeoff and injection burns to and from the moon but otherwise a masterpiece well done
Simply amazing! I have watched this many times on the DK2 and I was still blown away.
Simply the best!\n\n10/10

SUCH A GOOD EXPERIENCE! Fantasticly made!

Nicely done.  A very comfortable experience, and the interactive parts are fun, though certainly not especially challenging (but I'm biased that way, most people won't have a flight background... so it's probably a good fit/challenge for the average viewer).

The models are decent... and the rendering smooth and effective.  It's a great way for people that weren't around during that heady time to have a taste of what the world experienced watching this unfold.

Another great way to introduce people to VR.

reviewText: Powerful stuff and a nice one to show the parents.

Visited the National Space Centre in Leicester over the Easter holidays.
This was better (and cheaper).  No queues, everything working!

It's an hour or two's ride, but a very well put together package.
The interactive version is simple, but satisfying.
Oddly I had a lot of trouble with the lunar landing on the 2D screen (lacked sense of motion), but it was a doddle in VR.

Oh, worked fine on the Oculus DK 2.
Wow, 10/10 Would visit the moon again.

If you're looking for a high quality example of what VR can do when presenting historical events in a compelling way, this is your ticket.

It's clear a lot of time and effort went in to putting this together. The interiors of the modules are gorgeous, with what appears to be a meticulous attention to detail. The sound bites, sound effects, as well as the music are all well suited to the events, and the sense of presence they achieve is pretty amazing. It's hard not to get emotional when you launch in to space.

It takes about 35 minutes to run through, and in my opinion is very much worth the price of admission. I can't wait to demo this to my friends and relatives.

I highly recommend this Experience, as I can't stop watching this and play it over and over again! Great audio soundtrack as well! Well worth the $15, also everyone I've showed this too gets goosebumps as well!
Quite short but absolutly beautiful\nNot worth 15€ tho, maybe more like 10
it was an amazing short experience anyone with a HMD should check out

Having followed this and experienced the previous beta versions - Apollo 11 was always impressive.  Now with CV1 launch (and slowwww shipping) - Apollo 11 has been released to coincide.  It's now a much more complete and even more impressive experience with interactive elements.  The sense of realism as you orbit earth and the moon feels far more realistic than Elite Dangerous (I'm an Elite Dangerous VR pilot/fan).\n\nI have Adr1ft also but that seems very mundane compared to this.  I recommend to everyone who loves VR and the history of the Apollo space program.
My favourite VR title

Great experience, well worth taking the time.  Never appreciated how tight the conditions were, and while some of the transitions were a bit stomach churning, that added to the experience of wonder for me.
This game brought me to tears. It doesn't have much replayability, but it was a wild ride I'll never forget!
This game" is too short to be a game I am satisfied with to play
date: and too long and fairly boring to demo to something who is new to VR. You also don't get to interact with anything
recommended: they have added Vive controller support
hoursPlayed: but you just use them as a gamepad. They are not your arms and you cannot press buttons or throw stuff (come on!). Very unsatisfied with this product. Nausea city also...\n\nAdd more emphasis on motion controls and make a short demo option and then we'll talk."

reviewText:
Recorded this as my first ever VR video for my YouTube channel,
I though to myself why not start this channels VR journey with one of the
most important journeys in human history". And I can't do nothing but love
it! It was just amazing and space is amazing and everything with it was
amazing! I couldn't get my hands around how the interactive things worked though..
Failed every time.
But other than that
date:
a nice 40-50 minutes or so experience :)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pjxV3oExu18
Stay Rad Everybody!!
/RadiCarl"

reviewText: Wow, loved it!
Will not work on my dk2.. weird , other games do from oculus store,, can i get my money back? or a working version?
Pretty amazing experience, even with the Oculus DK2.

Inside the space ship is the best visuals but not as good as robot repair in the lab which is free. The moon looks like it needs more detail. The landscape around the launch looks weak. For 14.99 it is too much. I would pay like 5.00 bucks for it.\nThats a good price for this. Not what i expected for the price.

I really wanted to like this but on my HTC Vive this was a very poor and half-baked experience. It's quite clear that this demo was not put together with the best VR practices in mind. For example, the camera accelerates at random which produces an involuntary weird feeling in your stomach and knees. It's distracting. The movement does not use the HTC Vive controllers but your look angle, it's gross. The whole things is just akwardly staped together.

The interactive sections were boring and also half baked. Nothing about this demo is really interactive.

The trying-to-be-impressive shots of earth felt fake in their low resolutionness and their very obvious planarity. It was really hard to get into it.

I kindof somewhat liked the part on the moon as they do tell you a bit about what the mission was like and what the experiments did, and also the part where you are inside the launch and the lander were kind of fun. But again there is absolutely no attention given to any detail. Buzz Aldrin jumps around and doesn't care to jump through rocks, because they are all just fake props. It's all wrong and no visible efforts are made beyond the bare minimum. The whole thing lasted around an hour. It's worth $15 for me but I can imagine it wouldn't be for others.
Extrodinary. As a space entuthiast this was extremely moving, especielly the launch sequence where I was close to drop a tear. It really felt like you were there. I highly recommend this.
More of a techdemo than a real game, but it was still awesome to see the scale of the rocket, landing and docking. Dont expcect a game, expect a experience. Is it worth it? Yeah it was :)

Treat this more as a documentary. Several moments really wowed me and others who tried it,\n\nI have to admit, some of the mechanics were a little awkward with the Vive, but seemed serviceable. Landing on the moon I feel needs more of a tutorial, as it seemed too trial-and-error-y". After a few failed attempts
date: I wish I had a bit more instruction w.r.t. how this landing should be pulled off."

reviewText:
Reviewed with HTC Vive/SteamVR:

What a great all around experience. Being a history, space, NASA, Apollo, science and or flight nerd helps; but even that is not required. Better than Apollo exhibits at most museums, this gives you a chance to feel like you are part of the Apollo mission from the Astronaut's perspective. No point in getting too detailed, but the experience is set up nicely with a very inspirational opening, puts you on the pad and then inserts you into one of the most dangerous and awe inspiring missions ever undertaken by NASA. Witness and PARTICIPATE in man's first steps on the Moon.

Visually very pleasing, the sense of presence in the modules is fantastic. The use of REAL Apollo 11 mission audio, along with some input from JFK and the astronauts themselves only deepens the entire thing. I continue to be amazed and inspired every time I replay it (and I do that often).

If you want a high level of interactivity and a true game, this may not be for you. If you want to feel like you were among the first men to travel to our moon and otherwise be astounded by some scenic vistas and immersive environments, don't hesitate to jump in.
Amazing experience, I'm blown away.

It's less a game, more a somewhat interactive documentary. If you've played a lot of Kerbal Space Program you'll probably nail the interactive bits first time :)

And OK, there's only really two big interactive bits, the rest being somewhat cutscene-y, and you don't get to use the HTC Vive Roomscale when you're no the moon... and it's a bit short.

But it's the closest thing I've ever seen to actually being there to witness one of humanity's greatest achievements.

I loved it!  Docking with the lander, then trying(I crashed three times before switching to cinematic mode for the landing) were cool but being on the Moon...
With actual audio from the mission, it really immerses you in it.
And you can stand/sit if you want so if not up for standing the hour or so it takes to complete, you don't have to.
My mom wanted to walk around on the Moon so I let her do that for a bit.  Was cool to watch her have so much fun in VR.

Apollo 11 VR is a brilliant program especially now you have updated it for keyboard control very realistic i have waited along time for a good apollo simulator ,maybe it would be good to have a bit more interaction added to the sim ie the stages on takeoff and injection burns to and from the moon but otherwise a masterpiece well done
Well crafted and enjoyable. Breathtaking experience.

This quite simply blew me away. My reaction ranged from goosebumps to full-out emotion - the Apollo program is one of the wonders of the world, and seeing it first-hand was incredible. They do their best to make it authentic. I didn't experience any motion-sickness or nausea, but it probably helped that it was all in space.
Amazing VR experience.  It was quite breathtaking to be part of the Apollo crew.  Very much recommended.
Pretty nice experience, just missing some shadows, especially on the moon surface. Still awesome.

An awe inspiring look at the Apollo 11 mission. While it lacks any AI or animation of Armstrong, Aldrin, or Collins while in the command module; the detail of the model is well done. For almost the entirety of the experience things seem very stiff due to the lifelessness of the crew. The only exception to this is when you exit the LEM and can walk/teleport around while Neil hops around on the moons surface. The sense of presence that SteamVR provides is amazing and being able to feel like you are actually standing on the moon looking up at the LEM is absolutly mesmerizing.\n\nEven with its shortcomings, and the thousand yard stare of the astronauts, the overall experience is great. If you have a VR system and have any interest in Space this is definitely a must buy experience. The begining camera flyin around the rocket is another highlight that will leave your jaw firmly affixed to the ground. I'm really looking forward to more of these experiences that use the power of VR to let you relive watershed moments from our history.

I really enjoyed, and learned a lot from this, Some of the floating in space scenes were a bit long and I wish the astronauts in the cockpit were  moving around more instead of just looking around, Even so that was easily the best vr expirence I have had so far.
Simply amazing! I have watched this many times on the DK2 and I was still blown away.
Simply the best!\n\n10/10

SUCH A GOOD EXPERIENCE! Fantasticly made!

My story: Went to the moon ---- found out it was not made of cheese ---- came home and wound up people who don't believe I had been to the moon.
My favourite VR title
Wow, 10/10 Would visit the moon again.

If you're looking for a high quality example of what VR can do when presenting historical events in a compelling way, this is your ticket.

It's clear a lot of time and effort went in to putting this together. The interiors of the modules are gorgeous, with what appears to be a meticulous attention to detail. The sound bites, sound effects, as well as the music are all well suited to the events, and the sense of presence they achieve is pretty amazing. It's hard not to get emotional when you launch in to space.

It takes about 35 minutes to run through, and in my opinion is very much worth the price of admission. I can't wait to demo this to my friends and relatives.

This experience sucessfully captures some of the most exciting moments of the Apollo 11 mission. It isn't perfect, but pulls you in and gives you the feeling of being there". Walking on the moon is just amazing and a dream (virtually) come true.\n\nFor those who feel nausea: It should help to use the teleport function to move around on the landing site  rather than locomotion via the touchpad."
Anything about space I'm hooked, I loved this immensely... VR is a wonderful medium for interactive documentaries I look forward to future space travel 👍
Wow, loved it!
This game" is too short to be a game I am satisfied with to play
date: and too long and fairly boring to demo to something who is new to VR. You also don't get to interact with anything
recommended: they have added Vive controller support
hoursPlayed: but you just use them as a gamepad. They are not your arms and you cannot press buttons or throw stuff (come on!). Very unsatisfied with this product. Nausea city also...\n\nAdd more emphasis on motion controls and make a short demo option and then we'll talk."

reviewText:
Best VR experience to date.

I played The Climb, Project Cars and lots of demos in VR with Oculus Rift DK2, i raccomand playing this one because it is realistic like no one, it is amazing for space extusiasts (like me) and others too, it gives you the sensaction to be in the actual situation!

Best VR game.

Its not really a game. There are a few interactive" sections but they are not really that interesting. The controls are also very responsive. The worst part is the walking around the moon part which is just terrible. As an experience its a mixed bag. I am a huge NASA space nut. I did really feel like I was in the command module on the launch pad. But the experience is marred by long load times between sections where you are placed into a grey space with nothing in it which immediately takes you out of the experience. I would suggest avoiding the interactive sections
date: they are not really that good best just to sit back and enjoy the ride for what it is. As an experience I would give it a 7 out of 10 which I would rate higher except for the long load times between events. As a game I would rate it 2 of 10
hoursPlayed: they should have skipped putting in interactive expreiences as they were really poorly done."

reviewText: One of the best space games i've ever played!\nThere isn't much gameplay, but the graphics are nice and it's very immersive.

Wow. Seriously. Absolutely stunning. A bit buggy at times, and can make you feel motion sick, but really, wow. It's on a whole another level, along with the likes of theBlu for demo experiences. And, on top of this, it lasts for nearly an hour.

I won't go into detail but will say that if you have a VR headset and are interested in space travel this is a must buy. It isn't perfect, and not an overly long experience (maybe 30 mins?) but the sense of presense and unique perspective it gives you is unparalled by anything even Imax experiences can give you.
This game brought me to tears. It doesn't have much replayability, but it was a wild ride I'll never forget!

Great experience, well worth taking the time.  Never appreciated how tight the conditions were, and while some of the transitions were a bit stomach churning, that added to the experience of wonder for me.

I was a backer on the KS and after trying the demo which I quite enjoyed, I finally put myself in the full experience on my Vive. Have to say I'm quite underwhelmed by the full experience. It's just very uncomfortable to be in. The outside of the rocket shots where you are floating in space and being pulled around with the camera moving is horribly sickness inducing. In fact I'm trying to still get over it as I type this review.

Also there needed to be better loading screens than what was  implemented. You just get kicked out of the experience and see the steam compositor with a bit of text saying LOADING. This really takes you out and it happens often. Loading scenes needed to have been done better as this is quite immersion breaking.

The best part was the shuttle launch, the rest was pretty boring and lack of interaction. Specially on the Vive makes for a dull experience. The moon itself looked awful, as did the landing module and the American flag. Really lacking polish and woe factor.

The audio and radio chatter is quite nice but looking around the moon, i didn't feel immersed in the whole experience.

Graphics could have been a lot better, audio doesn't always sound too good and it's like it was heavily compressed even in good headphones it didn't sound all that crisp and clear.

I'd say try and grab it when it's on sale but not really worth full price. More care and time was needed to add polish to this experience. It is informative and educational and for that I have to commend the team, but it was underwhelming and could have been far better.

Breathtaking experience. I supported them in the beta program long before they were on Steam. They've come a HUGE way since then. This is a must try experience. The music is gob-smackingly awesome as well. The first time I tried it was on my DK2.. now on my Vive.. Even just experiencing it on the DK2, I literally had tears coming out when I passed by the moon and saw the Eagle detach from the Command Module. Music was a big factor in this of course, as it pushed me over the edge.
Really liked this game" Cannot wait to see more of the same style"

I'm giving this a positive review, because I think it's pretty much the first of a long line of similar experiences. One of the most immersive hours I've spent on the Rift since I got it a couple of days ago.

That being said, it's very, very short. It took an hour from start to finish. I think £4.99 might be a better price point for a one hour game that has very little replayability.
This is an amazing experience. Anyone of any age who is the slightest bit interested in space must experience this. Very well put together for a very acceptable price.

This game does a lot of things right. It's accuarte, provides a really good sense of the scale of everything (especially the size of the Saturn V), and is an enjoyable hour long experience.

This game could use some better textures, more first-person experiences, and some room-scale moonwalking (though that may be disorienting). I would also have liked to be able to move around in the spaceships and get to interact with the controls more directly. As it was, I couldn't read all of the labels in the cockpit.

Granted, a lot of these flaws are because this was developed more for the Oculus which doesn't have room scale but it would have been nice to take advantage of that.
voteText: No ratings yet 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: What a great VR experience, for kids and adults alike. Recommended to everyone as a reminder of the real heroes of the 20th century and a story that needs to be regularly shared. NASA and the broader space community should embrace this new technology to inspire the next generation to do more than just play games.

I feel like this title deserves recommending but begrudgingly so.

It is passably well made and there is value to it, but only in a specific niche.

It's not a simulation, it's kind of a documentary, but not really. As ride alongs on rockets go it's somewhat lackluster and definately lacks any replayability of it's compitors. Objects in the game are well modelled but often the low quality textures take you out of the experience. As it stands the visuals are okay. The strongest thing it has going for is it's use of music to set the mood. It's also quite short.

On the one hand, this is one of the first VR experiences of its type and that is applaudable. Additionally the small user base for VR means it's got to be hard to recoop development costs... But even so it feels overpriced. See even as a VR headset user I'm not going to get anything more out of this and I got little it of it as it was. It's a good demo for showing off to friends to give them an idea of where VR experiences are headed... But it's nothing spectacular in it's own right.

Unless of course you know nothing about the Apollo 11 mission, never heard the JFK speech before, generally experienced little of the moon landing media... Then it's a rather impressive introduction to those things. As a one off.

But for the same money you could buy 3 feature length movies on the topic just as moving and inspiring if not more so. Is it fare to compare the product of a small studio to Hollywood productions? Does that alone justify paying more? That's up to the consumer.

One area they had the chance to stand out was the interactive sequences. Unfortunately experiences are super simplistic and dumbed down or otherwise limited by the controls, plus few and far between. There are a lot of almost unnecassary drawn out external camera shots which while setup to set the mood, would be much more compelling if the player was given control durin them, to take them at their own pace and explore as they will.

That's not to say I don't think the developer hasn't put effort in. But while they are showing off some of the strengths of the medium they are drasticly underutilising others. There is some educational value to the product and it does stand up as a demo" but it's not much more then that. I also definately want the developer to make their money back on it so we can see more such VR experiences and better ones as the medium is explored more.

As it stands
date: unless you have a lot of friends you are trying to show VR off to
recommended:
have teenagers in the household or are really obsessed with the American space program... I'd wait till this product is on sale. Hopefully when it is it will sell well.



"

reviewText: Mostly long slow shots with a lot of speaches and interviews. I really enjoyed it, like a trip to a museum. Also check out Titans of Space.
The Interactive" parts are minimal and non responsive. Being on the surface was the only part that seemed to receive the commands from my controller 100% of the time."
